abstract: After The Wall Street Journal reported that Time Warner is considering selling off part of its cable holdings to invest more in the Internet, CNNMoney.com’s Paul R. La Monica suggested that Carl Icahn, the billionaire financier who tried to break up the company, may deserve some credit if the company chooses this route. An analyst at Prudential Equity Group said she found Tuesday’s report from the Journal hard to believe, however.
lead_paragraph: After The Wall Street Journal reported that Time Warner is considering selling off part of its cable holdings to invest more in the Internet, CNNMoney.com’s Paul R. La Monica suggested that Carl Icahn, the billionaire financier who tried to break up the company, may deserve some credit if the company chooses this route. An analyst at Prudential Equity Group said she found Tuesday’s report from the Journal hard to believe, however.

headline.main: Should Time Warner Dial Back on Cable?
